cHuRV7Sl.title: Infrared laser spectroscopy of the ν2 fundamental band of D2O+
cHuRV7Sl.abstract: The ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 O + was recorded in the region 1000–1150 cm −1 using a tunable diode laser spectrometer with velocity-modulation technique. The ions were produced in an ac glow discharge of a mixture of D 2 O and He. Sixty-four transitions with N ⩽ 11 and K ⩽ 3 were assigned and fitted, yielding a set of improved rotational, spin-rotational and centrifugal distortion constants of the ground and ν 2 vibrational states. The ν 2 band origin was determined to be 1044.28594(39) cm −1 . Keywords Rovibrational spectrum D 2 O + Velocity modulation 1 Introduction The water cation (H 2 O + ) has been the subject of many experimental studies since Whipple conjectured its presence in comet tails in 1950 [1] . Lew and Heiber first reported the visible spectrum of the A ∼ 2 A 1 - X ∼ 2 B 1 transition of H 2 O + in 1973 [2] . It was followed by a detailed analysis by Lew [3] . The high resolution absorption spectra of the A ∼ 2 A 1 - X ∼ 2 B 1 transition have also been recorded in the visible and near-infrared region [4–7] . In the IR region, the ν 3 band was detected in absorption in the region 3100–3400 cm −1 using a tunable difference frequency spectrometer [8] . The ν 2 and 2 ν 2 − ν 2 bands were recorded in the region 1270–1750 cm −1 using a diode laser spectrometer [9] . The ν 1 and ν 2 + ν 3 − ν 2 bands were detected in the region 3180–3390 cm −1 using a color center laser spectrometer [10] . All the above-mentioned absorption spectra were measured with the velocity modulation technique [11] . The far-infrared laser magnetic resonance spectroscopy has also been used to measure the pure rotational transitions of H 2 O + in the ground state [12,13] . Very detailed information has been obtained for the spectra and structure of H 2 O + from these experimental work. In contrast to the normal species, spectroscopy studies of the deuterated species, HDO + and D 2 O + , are rather scarce. To the best of our knowledge, no high resolution studies have been reported for HDO + , while only two for D 2 O + . Lew and Groleau gave an detailed analysis of 15 bands of the A ∼ 2 A 1 - X ∼ 2 B 1 transition of D 2 O + in 1987 [14] . The observed combination differences in the ground state were used to determine the rotational and spin-rotational constants for the ν 2 = 0, 1 and 3 bending vibrational states. Very recently Gan et al. recorded an absorption spectra of D 2 O + in the visible and near-infrared region using optical heterodyne magnetic rotation enhanced velocity modulation spectroscopy [7] . They obtained a set of molecular constants and rotational term values for the observed vibronic bending levels of the A ∼ 2 A 1 state, with the molecular constants of the ground state fixed at the values derived by Lew and Groleau [14] . Additional low resolution data are available from the photoelectron spectra of H 2 O and D 2 O [15] and the vibrational spectra of H 2 O + , HDO + and D 2 O + isolated in solid neon [16] . Accurate three-dimensional potential energy surface and electric dipole moment functions for the X ∼ 2 B 1 and A ∼ 2 A 1 states of H 2 O + , HDO + and D 2 O + have been calculated by Weis et al. [17] and Brommer et al. [18] . In this paper, we report a direct absorption measurement of the ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 O + ( X ∼ 2 B 1 ) in the region 1000–1150 cm −1 using a infrared diode laser spectrometer with velocity modulation technique. The observed lines were used to derive a set of improved rotational, spin-rotational and centrifugal distortion constants of the ground and ν 2 vibrational states. The improved molecular constants of the ground state will be helpful to refine the term values of the A ∼ 2 A 1 state or to assist the possible astronomical search. 2 Experiment The infrared diode laser spectrometer used to record the spectrum of D 2 O + has been described in details elsewhere [19] . Briefly, the infrared radiations were emitted from the lead-salt diode laser mounted in a liquid-nitrogen cooled Dewar (Model L5736, Laser Components). After a single pass through a 10-mm bore, 1-m long water-cooled discharge cell, the main part of the laser beam was detected by a liquid-nitrogen cooled HgCdTe detector (Judson Technologies). The output of this detector was demodulated by a lock-in amplifier at the frequency of the discharge. A small portion of the laser beam was reflected by the front CaF 2 window of the discharge cell and then chopped by a mechanical chopper with a frequency at 600 Hz. This chopped beam was divided into two parts further, one for a reference gas cell and the other for a 1-inch Ge etalon, and then detected by two HgCdTe detectors separately. The output of these two detectors was demodulated at the frequency of the mechanical chopper by two lock-in amplifiers separately. The scan of the current of the diode laser and the data acquisition from three lock-in amplifiers were controlled by a home-developed LabView program simultaneously. The D 2 O + ions were generated by an ac glow discharge with a flowing gas mixture of bubbled D 2 O vapor (Merck, 99.9%) and high-purity helium (>99.999%). Velocity modulation technique was used for the detection [11] . The typical discharge frequency and peak-to-peak current were 38 kHz and 300 mA. The optimal gas mixture was at a total pressure of ∼1.5 Torr., which was measured by a Pirani vacuum gauge at the downstream of the discharge cell. Two diodes were used to cover the 1000–1150 cm −1 region. The absorption spectra of D 2 O + were calibrated by using the accurate line positions of CH 3 OH and SO 2 from the HITRAN database [20] and the Ge etalon fringes (FSR ∼ 0.049 cm −1 ). The absolute accuracy of the calibration was estimated to be 0.005 cm −1 . 3 Results and analysis The asymmetry parameter κ = 2 B - A - C A - C is −0.682 and −0.713 for the ν 2 = 0 and 1 vibrational states of D 2 O + ( X ∼ 2 B 1 ) , respectively, in which the A , B and C rotational constants were taken from Ref. [14] . The ν 2 fundamental mode obeys the b -type selection rules for an asymmetric top: Δ N = 0, ± 1; Δ K a = ±1(±3, ± 5, …); Δ K c = ±1(±3, ± 5, …). The interaction of the single unpaired electron and the rotation motion splits each rotational level into two spin components ( F 1 : J = N + 1/2; F 2 : J = N − 1/2). The Δ J = Δ N doublets have the dominant intensity while the Δ J ≠ Δ N doublets only have reasonable intensity at low N . The nuclear spin of the deuterium atom ( I = 1) gives a nuclear spin statistical weight of 3 for rotational levels with ( K a , K c ) = ( e , e ), ( o , o ) and 6 for levels with ( K a , K c ) = ( e , o ), ( o , e ), when the vibrational eigenfunction of the lower level is totally symmetric. The rotational structure of the ν 2 = 0 and 1 vibrational states of D 2 O + ( X ∼ 2 B 1 ) can be described by the A -reduced asymmetric top Hamiltonian H R of Watson [21] with additional A -reduced spin-rotation Hamiltonian H SR of Brown and Sears [22] : (1) H R = AN a 2 + BN b 2 + CN c 2 - Δ N N 4 - Δ NK N 2 N a 2 - Δ K N a 4 - 1 2 [ δ N N 2 + δ K N a 2 , N + 2 + N - 2 ] + + H N N 6 + H NK N 4 N a 2 + H KN N 2 N a 4 + H K N a 6 + ⋯ (2) H SR = ε aa N a S a + ε bb N b S b + ε cc N c S c + Δ N S N 2 ( N · S ) + 1 2 Δ NK S [ N 2 , N a S a ] + + Δ KN S N a 2 ( N · S ) + Δ K S N a 3 S a + ⋯ The prediction and fitting of the ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 O + were carried out by using Pickett’s program SPFIT/SPCAT [23] . The initial search for the ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 O + was based on the predicted line positions with molecular constants determined by Lew and Groleau [14] . Fig. 1 shows a portion of observed spectrum around 1006 cm −1 . The spin-rotational splitting and the nuclear spin statistical weight are well illustrated in Fig. 1 . The rotational temperature was estimated to be about 500 K by comparing the relative intensity of observed lines with that calculated by the program SPCAT [23] at different trial temperature. Observed lines with lower rotational numbers ( N ⩽ 4, K a ⩽ 2) could be assigned straightforward according to the prediction. Those lines with higher rotational numbers could only be assigned by sequentially assigning and fitting the data. Occasionally, due to the incomplete discrimination of the strong absorption of neutral species by velocity modulation technique, some strong transitions of the ν 2 band of D 2 16 O [24] could be recorded in the same laser mode as the ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 O + in an opposite phase, as shown in Fig. 1 . Table 1 lists all the observed lines which were assigned to the ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 O + . The observed lines were used to fit the molecular constants for the ν 2 = 0 and 1 vibrational states of D 2 O + simultaneously. The combination differences from the electronic spectrum [7,14] were not included because they degraded either the parameter values or the standard deviation. Various trial fits were used to test the significance of the sextic rotational centrifugal distortion constants and the quartic spin-rotational distortion constants. Since only rovibrational transitions with K a ⩽ 3 but with N up to 11 were recorded in this work, the H N constant was included instead of the H K constant. The inclusion of the Δ K S and Δ KN S constants was found to be necessary to fit the data satisfactorily. In the final fit, 64 lines were used to fit 29 parameters, namely, the vibrational band origin, all the rotational parameters, the quartic rotational centrifugal distortion parameters, the diagonal spin-rotation parameters, H N , Δ K S and Δ KN S , while the rest of the parameters were fixed at zero. The standard deviation of the fit was 0.0035 cm −1 . The resulting parameters are listed in Table 2 . The differences between the observed line positions and the calculated are also listed in Table 1 . 4 Discussion and conclusions The molecular constants derived from this work are compared with those of Lew and Groleau from the electronic emission spectrum [14] and Weis et al. from the ab initio calculations [17] , as listed in Table 2 . Our results are in good agreement with those of Lew and Groleau [14] but with much higher precision. The B and C constants for the ν 2 = 0 and 1 states calculated by Weis et al. [17] are in excellent agreement with the experiment, but the A constants have large negative deviations, which is very similar to the case for H 2 O + [9] . The calculated quartic rotational distortion constants for the ground state are also in good agreement with the experiment. The newly determined ground state molecular constants of D 2 O + can be used to calculate the term values of rotational levels with N ⩽ 11 and K ⩽ 3 accurately, and they will be helpful to refine the term values of the A ∼ 2 A 1 state or to assist the possible astronomical search. Lew and Groleau determined the ν 2 band origin of D 2 O + by simply taking the difference between r R 0, N (0) lines in the Π sub-bands of (14, 0) and (14, 1) of the A ∼ 2 A 1 - X ∼ 2 B 1 transition [14] . But their reported value, 1044.27(5) cm −1 , is very close to our result, 1044.28594(39) cm −1 . The calculated band origin from Weis et al. [17] and Brommer et al. [18] are 1048.1 and 1047.43 cm −1 , respectively, which are higher than this experiment. The observed ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 16 O + isolated in neon matrix is 1040.5 cm −1 [16] , showing a red shift to the band origin in the gas phase. In conclusion, the ν 2 fundamental band of D 2 O + was recorded for the first time by using a tunable diode laser spectrometer with velocity modulation technique. A set of improved molecular constants for the ground and ν 2 vibrational states was derived. The excellent agreement of molecular constants between the experiment and the ab initio MRCI calculations suggests the high accuracy of the latter. D7nauV6r.title: Extended measurement of the v2(1-←0+) band of H3O+ by mid-infrared diode laser spectroscopy
D7nauV6r.abstract: Twenty-five new R-branch lines of the v2 (1 -←0+) band of H3O+ are measured using diode laser velocity modulation spectroscopy between 1070 and 1230 cm-1. The H3O+ ions are produced in a high voltage ac discharge with water diluted in helium. The observed lines together with all the previously published measurements are fit to the standard vibration-rotational Hamiltonian of an oblate symmetric top, yielding a set of improved molecular constants. All the sextic centrifugal distortion constants for both 0+ and 1- states are determined precisely. The observed R(13,0) transition is shifted about -0.129 cm-1 from its calculated value, indicating that a near degeneracy exists between the (13, 0)+ and (13, 3)- ground-state rotation-inversion levels. ©2007 Chinese Physical Society and IOP Publishing Ltd.

4QAfpVNj.title: Infrared diode laser spectroscopy of the Kr-N2O van der Waals complex: The v1 symmetric stretch region of N2O
4QAfpVNj.abstract: The rovibrational spectra of four isotopomers of the Kr-N2O van der Waals complex, namely 82Kr-N2O, 83Kr-N 2O, 84Kr-N2O and 86Kr-N2O, were measured in the v1 vibrational band region of the N2O monomer (∼ 1285 cm-1) using a tunable diode laser spectrometer to probe a pulsed supersonic slit jet. Rotational constants for both ground and excited vibrational states of these four isotopomers were accurately determined. The band-origin of Kr-N2O was observed to shift by +0.1065 cm -1 from that of the monomer. The band-origin shifts of Rg-N 2O (Rg = Ne, Ar, Kr) in the v1 vibrational band region could also be well explained by the model based on a Buckingham intermolecular potential [W.A. Herrebout, H.-B. Qian, H. Yamaguchi and B.J. Howard, J. Mol. Spectrosc. 189, 235 (1998)]. But the band-origin shift of He-N2O was found to deviate significantly from this model. The possible reason is discussed and the band-origin shift of Xe-N2O predicted. © 2011 Taylor & Francis.

PnBpEZMD.title: A new analysis of the ν2 fundamental band of H 2O+*
PnBpEZMD.abstract: This paper reports that the absorption spectra of H2O + have been measured by tunable mid-infrared diode laserspectroscopy in the spectral range of 1100-1380 cm-1. The H2O + ions are generated in an AC glow discharge of the gaseous mixtures of H2O/He and detected with the velocity modulation technique. Forty new lines are assigned to theν2 fundamental band of H 2O+(2B1). The observed lines together with other data published previously are fitted to the standard effective Hamiltonian of an asymmetric top, yielding a set of improved rotational constants, spin-rotation constants and their quartic and sextic centrifugal distortion constants for the ν2=1 vibrational state of H2O +. © 2008 Chin. Phys. Soc. and IOP Publishing Ltd.

tl6iBL9H.title: Rovibrational spectrum and potential energy surface of the N 2-N2O van der Waals complex
tl6iBL9H.abstract: The rovibrational spectrum of the N2-N2O van der Waals complex has been recorded in the N2O ν1 region (∼1285 cm-1) using a tunable diode laser spectrometer to probe a pulsed supersonic slit jet. The observed transitions together with the data observed previously in the N2O ν3 region are analyzed using a Watson S-reduced asymmetric rotor Hamiltonian. The rotational and centrifugal distortion constants for the ground and excited vibrational states are accurately determined. The band-origin of the spectrum is determined to be 1285.73964(14) cm-1. A restricted two-dimensional intermolecular potential energy surface for a planar structure of N2-N2O has been calculated at the CCSD(T) level of theory with the aug-cc-pVDZ basis sets and a set of mid-bond functions. With the intermolecular distance fixed at the ground state value R = 3.6926 , the potential has a global minimum with a well depth of 326.64 cm-1 at θN2 = 11.0° and θN2O = 84.3° and has a saddle point with a barrier height of 204.61 cm-1 at θN2 = 97.4° and θN2O = 92.2°, where θN2 (θN2O) is the enclosed angle between the N-N axis (N-N-O axis) and the intermolecular axis. © 2011 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

186BAXRy.title: Infrared spectra and tunneling dynamics of the N2-D2O and OC-D2O complexes in the v2 bend region of D 2O
186BAXRy.abstract: The rovibrational spectra of the N2-D2O and OC-D 2O complexes in the v2 bend region of D2O have been measured in a supersonic slit jet expansion using a rapid-scan tunable diode laser spectrometer. Both a-type and b-type transitions were observed for these two complexes. All transitions are doubled, due to the heavy water tunneling within the complexes. Assuming the tunneling splittings are the same in Ka = 0 and Ka = 1, the band origins, all three rotational and several distortion constants of each tunneling state were determined for N2-D2O in the ground and excited vibrational states, and for OC-D2O in the excited vibrational state, respectively. The averaged band origin of OC-D2O is blueshifted by 2.241 cm-1 from that of the v2 band of the D2O monomer, compared with 1.247 cm-1 for N2-D2O. The tunneling splitting of N2-D2O in the ground state is 0.16359(28) cm-1, which is about five times that of OC-D 2O. The tunneling splittings decrease by about 26% for N 2-D2O and 23% for OC-D2O, respectively, upon excitation of the D2O bending vibration, indicating an increase of the tunneling barrier in the excited vibrational state. The tunneling splittings are found to have a strong dependence on intramolecular vibrational excitation as well as a weak dependence on quantum number Ka. © 2013 AIP Publishing LLC.

wNz14pNy.title: Rovibrational spectrum and potential energy surface of the N2–N2O van der Waals complex
wNz14pNy.abstract: The rovibrational spectrum of the N 2 –N 2 O van der Waals complex has been recorded in the N 2 O ν 1 region (∼1285 cm −1 ) using a tunable diode laser spectrometer to probe a pulsed supersonic slit jet. The observed transitions together with the data observed previously in the N 2 O ν 3 region are analyzed using a Watson S -reduced asymmetric rotor Hamiltonian. The rotational and centrifugal distortion constants for the ground and excited vibrational states are accurately determined. The band-origin of the spectrum is determined to be 1285.73964(14) cm −1 . A restricted two-dimensional intermolecular potential energy surface for a planar structure of N 2 –N 2 O has been calculated at the CCSD(T) level of theory with the aug-cc-pVDZ basis sets and a set of mid-bond functions. With the intermolecular distance fixed at the ground state value R = 3.6926 Å, the potential has a global minimum with a well depth of 326.64 cm −1 at θ N 2 = 11.0° and θ N 2 O = 84.3° and has a saddle point with a barrier height of 204.61 cm −1 at θ N 2 = 97.4° and θ N 2 O = 92.2°, where θ N 2 ( θ N 2 O ) is the enclosed angle between the N–N axis (N–N–O axis) and the intermolecular axis. Keywords Rovibrational spectrum van der Waals complex N 2 –N 2 O 1 Introduction In the past three decades more than thirty van der Waals complexes containing nitrous oxide (N 2 O) have been studied by high resolution infrared and/or microwave spectroscopy [1] . These studies have provided a wealth of information on the structure, dynamics and intermolecular interactions in the N 2 O-containing complexes. Spectroscopic investigations of the N 2 –N 2 O and O 2 –N 2 O complexes are of atmospheric interest, because a precise characterization of the weak interactions between N 2 or O 2 and N 2 O is essential for accurate calculations of the N 2 or O 2 pressure-broadening coefficients of N 2 O [2] . The rotationally resolved infrared spectrum of the N 2 –N 2 O complex was first reported by Randall et al. [3] in the ν 3 asymmetric stretching mode region of N 2 O monomer. A near T-shaped geometry was determined from the rotational constants and rationalized by the construction of potentials using a distributed multipole and distributed dispersion model. In order to gain a more detailed structure of this complex, Leung [4] studied the rotational spectrum of 15 N 2 – 14 N 2 O using a pulsed molecular beam Fourier transform microwave spectrometer. With the rotational constants and the nuclear quadrupole coupling constants, four possible structures of 15 N 2 – 14 N 2 O were determined. These structures are all planar and approximately T-shaped, with N 2 forming the leg of the T. The 15 N 2 axis and the 14 N 2 O axis were found to make an angle of 13° and 81° with the intermolecular axis, respectively [4] . The infrared spectrum of the O 2 –N 2 O complex was first investigated in the nitrogen matrix [5] and later in the molecular beam [6] . The equilibrium structure of the O 2 –N 2 O complex was experimentally determined to be planar but with an effective out-of-plane angle of 23° [6] . The angles between the O 2 /N 2 O axis and the intermolecular axis were determined to be either θ O 2 = 58° and θ N 2 O = 77°, or θ O 2 = 122° and θ N 2 O = 100° [6] . The band-origin of O 2 –N 2 O in the N 2 O ν 3 region has a small shift of +0.36635 cm −1 from that of the N 2 O monomer [6] , compared with a large shift of +2.2327 cm −1 for N 2 –N 2 O [3] . To our knowledge, no high-level ab initio intermolecular potential energy surfaces (PES) have been reported for these two complexes. The present paper reports the observation and analysis of the rovibrational spectrum of N 2 –N 2 O in the ν 1 symmetric stretching mode region of N 2 O monomer. A set of improved molecular constants for the ground and excited vibrational states has been determined from a global analysis of our observed spectrum and the data observed previously in the N 2 O v 3 region [3] . An ab initio two-dimensional intermolecular potential energy surface for N 2 –N 2 O is used to determine the orientation of the monomers in the complex. 2 Experimental The rovibrational spectrum of N 2 –N 2 O was measured with a tunable infrared diode laser spectrometer which has been described in detail elsewhere [7,8] . A Pb-salt infrared diode laser was operated in a rapid scan mode [9] . The laser current was ramped by a laser controller (Laser Components, L5830) at a frequency of 1 kHz. The laser beam was reflected 120 times through a pulsed supersonic jet expansion by a pair of astigmatic mirrors. A home-made 30 mm × 200 μm slit nozzle was attached to a 0.8 mm pin-hole pulsed valve (General Valve series 9). An air-spaced internally coupled confocal Fabry–Perot interferometer (ic-FBI) [10] with a free spectral range of about 0.01 cm −1 was used for relative frequency calibration. The strong absorption lines of the N 2 O monomer in the slit jet and their accurate frequency positions in HITRAN [11] were used for absolute frequency calibration. The absolute accuracy of the frequency calibration was estimated to be about 0.0005 cm −1 . The direct absorption signal from the jet and the interferometer fringes were digitized by a two-channel 14-bit 50 MHz A/D card (NI PXI-5122) and transferred to an embedded controller (NI PXI-8186). A LabView program was developed to acquire and process the data. A software line-locking scheme with a strong absorption line of N 2 O in the slit jet as the wavelength reference was used to correct the laser frequency drift during signal averaging [12] . The N 2 –N 2 O complexes were generated in the supersonic expansion using about 0.3% N 2 O and 3% N 2 diluted in helium. The gases were pre-mixed in a gas cylinder before use. The optimal stagnation pressure was about 14 atmospheres. The opening time of the nozzle was about 1500 ms with a repetition rate of 5 Hz. The average pressure during valve operation in the vacuum chamber was 8.0 × 10 −3 mbar. 3 Results and analysis 3.1 Rotational analysis The absorption spectrum of N 2 –N 2 O has been measured in the spectral region between 1284.1 and 1285.9 cm −1 . Fig. 1 shows a portion of our observed spectrum. The spectrum was synthesized by several individual frequency scans. Each scan was averaged for more than 2000 gas pulses. The line-width of most isolated lines is about 0.002 cm −1 . Lines marked with an asterisk are due to absorption of N 2 O monomer in the slit jet. The spectrum observed in the N 2 O ν 1 region was very similar to that observed in the N 2 O ν 3 region [3] . The assignment was straightforward using a conventional Watson S -reduction Hamiltonian [13] and molecular constants reported in Ref. [3] . A total of 152 b -type transitions were assigned, with J up to 20 and K a up to 4, while no a -type transitions were found under the present sensitivity. Due to the limited spectral coverage of our diode lasers, most of these transitions belong to the Q - or P -branch. A global analysis of these transitions and 65 transitions assigned previously in the N 2 O ν 3 region [3] were performed to determine molecular constants for both ground and excited vibrational states using the SPFIT/SPCAT program [14] . In the final fit, the band-origin ν 0 , three rotational constants ( A , B , C ) and two centrifugal distortion constants ( D J , D JK ) for all three vibrational states were floated. The centrifugal distortion constants d 1 and d 2 for two excited vibrational states were constrained to their values in the ground state. Even with a largely expanded dataset, the centrifugal distortion constant D K could not be well determined and so was fixed at zero. The resulting molecular constants are listed in Table 1 and the observed transitions and their residues are given in Table SI of the supplementary material . The standard deviation of the fit is 0.00037 cm −1 , which is within the experimental uncertainty. A simulated spectrum with molecular constants in Table 1 and a rotational temperature of 8 K is shown in Fig. 1 b. The simulated spectrum of N 2 –N 2 O reproduces the observed spectrum very well. However, there are several lines whose observed intensities are significantly weaker than their predicted intensities, for example, the lines near 1284.573 and 1284.822 cm −1 . This discrepancy is still not understood. Other van der Waals complexes or clusters formed in the supersonic expansion of He/N 2 /N 2 O, such as He–N 2 O [7] , (N 2 O) 2 [15] and (N 2 O) 3 [16] , are also possible to be detected in the N 2 O ν 1 region. No transitions of He–N 2 O were identified due to the relatively high rotational temperature in our jet. Some lines could be readily assigned to the transitions of the nonpolar isomer of (N 2 O) 2 with high values of J and K a [15] . But many weak lines and even several strong lines remain unassigned. For example, two strong lines which are partially overlapped by the 1 11 –2 20 and 1 10 –2 21 K -doublets around 1284.39 cm −1 were not able to be assigned to any of the above-mentioned complexes. The newly determined molecular constants for the ground and N 2 O ν 3 -excited vibrational states are in good agreement with those reported in Ref. [3] except D JK in the ground state. In previous study [3] , D J and D JK for the N 2 O ν 3 -excited vibrational state were constrained to their ground state values. Our results show D JK for the ground state, 348(17) kHz, is slightly smaller than that for the N 2 O ν 3 -excited excited vibrational state, 511(59) kHz. The determined centrifugal distortion constants for N 2 –N 2 O are very similar to those for its isoelectronic complex CO–N 2 O [17–19] . The band-origin of our observed spectrum is determined to be ν 0 = 1285.73964(14) cm −1 , with a blue-shift of +0.8363 cm −1 from that of N 2 O monomer, compared with +2.2325 cm −1 in the N 2 O ν 3 region [3] . 3.2 Structural analysis The effective structure of N 2 –N 2 O was derived from the rotational constants using a similar approach which was applied to CO–N 2 O by Qian and Howard [18] . Assuming the geometries of the monomers remain unchanged upon complexation, the structure of N 2 –N 2 O is defined by four Jacobi coordinates as shown in Fig. 2 , where R is the intermolecular distance between the N 2 and N 2 O centers of mass, θ N 2 is the enclosed angle between the N–N axis and R , θ N 2 O is the enclosed angle between the N–N–O axis and R , and φ is the dihedral angle between the two subunits. The calculated inertial defects ( Δ = I c − I b − I a ) for three vibrational states are 1.98(8), 2.02(9) and 1.99(12) amu Å 2 , respectively. The small positive values of the inertial defect indicate the complex is planar ( φ = 0). For a planar structure, R can be determined from C constant by the following formula: R = k μ 1 C - 1 b N 2 O - 1 b N 2 1 / 2 , where μ is the reduced mass of the complex, b N 2 O , b N 2 are the rotational constants of N 2 O [20] and N 2 [21] , k is a conversion factor (505 379 MHz amu Å 2 ). The distance R in the ground state, 3.6926(3) Å, increases slightly to 3.6929(3) and 3.6954(4) Å in the N 2 O ν 1 and ν 3 -excited vibrational states, respectively, indicating the complex is slightly expanded upon vibrational excitation. For a planar molecule, only two out of the three rotational constants are independent because the moments of inertia have a planar relationship: I c ≈ I a + I b . The C constant has been used to determine R , so only one more constant, A or B , remains to determine the angles θ N 2 and θ N 2 O . Obviously their values cannot be determined separately. In the absence of isotopic substitution data it is impossible to determine the orientation of the subunits within the complex from the rotational constants. In order to get some indications about the structural angles, Randall et al. calculated the intermolecular potential energy curves for N 2 –N 2 O in the T-shaped form ( θ N 2 + θ N 2 O = 90 ∘ ) and the slipped parallel form ( θ N 2 = θ N 2 O ) using a distributed multipole and distributed dispersion model [3] . Considering the rough approximations of this model and constrains used in the calculation, it is necessary to construct a more precise intermolecular potential energy surface for N 2 –N 2 O. For this purpose, an ab initio two-dimensional intermolecular potential energy surface will be calculated and used to determine the possible structure in the next section. 4 Intermolecular potential The N 2 and N 2 O monomers were assumed to be rigid and were frozen at their equilibrium structures: r (N–N) = 1.0977 Å for N 2 [21] , r (N–N) = 1.1273 Å and r (N–O) = 1.1851 Å for N 2 O [22] , respectively. The intermolecular potential energy of N 2 –N 2 O for a given geometry was calculated at the coupled-cluster singles and doubles with perturbative triples [CCSD(T)] level [23] , using aug-cc-pVDZ basis sets [24] for all atoms supplemented with bond functions (3s3p2d) [25] placed at the midpoint of R . The supermolecular approach was used, where the intermolecular interaction energy was the difference between the dimer energy and the energy of the N 2 and N 2 O monomers. The full counterpoise correction [26] was used to account for the basis set superposition error. All the calculations were carried out with the Molpro 2009.1 package [27] . The intermolecular potential was calculated for geometries with R fixed at its averaged ground state value, 3.6926 Å, with angles θ N 2 and θ N 2 O varied from 0 to 360° in steps of 10°, and with φ fixed at 0. A total of 1369 data points for the intermolecular potential energy were obtained ( Table S2 in the supplemental material ). The PES was constructed using the cubic spline interpolation method. The global minimum occurs at θ N 2 = 11.0° and θ N 2 O = 84.3°, with a well depth of 326.64 cm −1 . Saddle point between the two equivalent minima ( θ N 2 = 11.0° or 191.0°) occurs at θ N 2 = 97.4° and θ N 2 O = 92.2°, with a barrier height of 204.61 cm −1 , which implies a hindered in-plane bending motion of the N 2 subunit. Fig. 3 shows constant energy contours of the two-dimensional PES with R and φ fixed at 3.6926 Å and 0, respectively. 5 Discussion and conclusion The equilibrium structural angles of the complex, predicted from the restricted two-dimensional intermolecular potential, are θ N 2 = 11.0° and θ N 2 O = 84.3°. This equilibrium structure is in good agreement with the third possible structure of 15 N 2 – 14 N 2 O (Fig. 6iii in Ref. [4] ) determined from the nuclear quadrupole coupling constants, in which the N 2 axis is pointing towards the terminal N nuclei of N 2 O and the O end of N 2 O is closer to the N 2 monomer than the N end. From the intermolecular PES of CO–N 2 O estimated with the model of Muenter [28] , the global minimum was found at R = 3.87 Å, θ CO = 15° and θ N 2 O = 86°, with a well depth of 322 cm −1 [18] . Obviously, the structural angles and well depth of N 2 –N 2 O are very similar to those of CO–N 2 O. The effective intermolecular distance of N 2 –N 2 O ( R = 3.6926 Å) is slightly shorter than that of CO–N 2 O ( R = 3.87 Å). The band-origin of CO–N 2 O in the N 2 O ν 3 region was observed to shift +2.9054 cm −1 from that of the N 2 O monomer [18] , compared with +2.2325 cm −1 for N 2 –N 2 O. A blue-shift of the band-origin means the intermolecular interaction becomes weaker upon vibrational excitation. From this point of view, the intermolecular interaction between CO and N 2 O might be slightly weaker than that between N 2 and N 2 O even though CO has a permanent electric dipole moment. A more quantitative comparison need to calculate the intermolecular PES of CO–N 2 O at the same level of computational method and basis sets for N 2 –N 2 O. Two internal motion states due to the internal motion of the 15 N 2 subunit have been observed in the pure rotational spectrum of 15 N 2 – 14 N 2 O [4] . Transitions between these two internal motion states are unobservable due to the forbidden of spin flip. In our infrared spectrum as well as that observed by Randall et al. [3] , no evidence of tunneling splitting was observed. The change of the barrier height upon the ν 1 vibrational excitation of N 2 O is probably too small to be resolved under our experimental conditions. In conclusion, the high resolution spectrum of the N 2 –N 2 O van der Waals complex has been recorded in the N 2 O ν 1 region. The rotational and centrifugal distortion constants for the ground and excited vibrational states are accurately determined from a global analysis of the available data in both the N 2 O ν 1 and ν 3 regions. The averaged intermolecular distance in the ground state is determined to be R = 3.6926 Å. The equilibrium structure of the complex, predicted from the restricted two-dimensional intermolecular potential energy, are θ N 2 = 11.0° and θ N 2 O = 84.3°. This structure shows a remarkable similarity to that of the isoelectronic complex CO–N 2 O. Acknowledgments This work has been supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant No. 10604019) and self-determined research funds of CCNU from the colleges’ basic research and operation of MOE (Grant No. CCNU09A02012). The authors thank Dr. Minghui Yang for his help on theoretical calculations. VIZa837m.title: Infrared diode laser spectroscopy of H2O-CO2 and D2O-CO2 complexes in the v2 bend region of water
VIZa837m.abstract: The rovibrational spectrum of H2O-CO2 and D 2O-CO2 weakly bound complexes has been measured in the v2 bend region of the water monomer by infrared diode laser absorption spectroscopy. Rotational and centrifugal distortion constants for different internal rotation states in the excited vibrational state have been determined. The band-origin of the spectrum is blue-shifted from that of the water monomer by 0.739 cm-1 for H2O-CO2 and 0.083 cm-1 for D2O-CO2, respectively. The tunneling splitting is reduced upon vibrational excitation by 0.00698(31) cm-1 for H2O-CO2 and 0.00044(17) cm -1 for D2O-CO2, respectively. © 2012 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

gPVyWjug.title: Efficacy and Safety of Intermittent Hormonal therapy(IHT) in Advanced Prostate Cancer Patients
gPVyWjug.abstract: Objective To compare the efficacy,safety and side-effects of IHT of advanced prostate cancer patients.Methods Thirty-six advanced prostate cancer patients were treated with hormonal therapy.The patients were divided into 2 groups,of 28 patients(groupA) used IHT;8 patients(groupB) were treated with castration only.The difference of clinical symptoms,serum PSA,survival rate,and side-effects of 2 groups were compared.Results The relief rates of group A 80.8%(18/28),groupB 70.6%(3/8).The mean serum PSA of group A decreased from 144.3(18.7-996.8)ng/mL to 15.8(0.02-28.9)ng/ml,group B decreased from 142.3(27.1-988.0)ng/mL to 27.6(6.0-62.1)ng/mL.The mean chemical recurrence rates of group A 34.6%(9/28),group B 58.3%(5/8).The mean chemical recurrence time of group A 22(6-65) month,group B 10(6-56) month.The mortality rates of group A 25%(7/28),group B 75%(6/8).85.5%(22/28) of group A were treated with IHT continuously.the side-effects rate of group A was low.Conclusion Bicalutamide is effective and safe as IHT for prostate cancer patients.

yTZLIpOm.title: Research on the adipose-derived stem cells combined with the extract of Eucommiol scaffold material to repair the rabbit mandible defect]
yTZLIpOm.abstract: To investigate the effect of Eucommiol on osteogenic differentiation of adipose-derived stem cells (ADSCs), and the feasibility of applying in mandibular defects repair using ADSCs combined with the extract of Eucommiol scaffold material.Forty-eight New Zealand rabbits were randomly divided into four groups and bilateral mandibular defect was prepared. Group A: Implanted the ADSCs combined with the extract of Eucommiol scaffold, group B: Implanted the ADSCs combined with hydroxyapatite materials, group C: Implanted hydroxyapatite materials, group D: The control group. All the experimental animals were sacrificed after 2, 4, 8, 12 weeks. Tissue samples were observed by gross observation, radiographic analysis, hematoxylin-eosin (HE) staining, scanning electron microscope (SEM). The value of imaging analysis and osteogenesis were evaluated. The results were analyzed by SPSS 17.0 statistical software.In vivo imaging and histological staining showed that the healing of bone defect and bone quality in group A was significantly better than those in the other groups. SEM showed well biocompatibility between composite material and tissue without inflammation reaction. By measuring and analyzing the dental CT data and new bone area, the bone in group A was obviously better than those in other groups (P < 0.05).The extract of Eucommiol can promote ADSCs into bone cells. The role of ADSCs combined with extract of Eucommiol scaffold materials has significant bone induction. It is expected that this material could become a new composite material and be used to fix the jaw bone defects.

htiapZYH.title: Bipolar Plasma Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor Combined with Intravesical Chemotherapy for the Treatment of Non Muscle-invasive Bladder Cancer in Cases
htiapZYH.abstract: Objective To investigate clinical effects of bipolar plasma transurethral resection of bladder tumor combined with postoperative intravesical chemotherapy by hydroxycamptothecine in the treatment of non muscle-invasive bladder cancer.Method 57 patients with non muscle-invasive bladder cancer were treated with bipolar plasma transurethral resection of bladder tumor combined with postoperative intravesical chemotherapy by hydroxycamptothecine(40 mg/40 mL).Results 57 patients with non muscle-invasive bladder cancer all were once ablated,5 patients relapsed during 3 months to 24 months of postoperative follow-up,which were treated by bipolar plasma transurethral resection of bladder tumor combined with postoperative intravesical chemotherapy by hydroxycamptothecine(40 mg/40 mL) again,and recurrence was not found after operation.Conclusion Bipolar plasma transurethral resection of bladder tumor combined with postoperative intravesical chemotherapy by hydroxycamptothecine is a safe,reliable,repeatable,and effective treatment with less trauma,few complications,and low recurrence rate for non muscle-invasive bladder cancer.
keywords: Bipolar plasma transurethral resection of bladder tumor

yTShTXC9.title: Study of agreement between electronic periodontal probe and manual probe for probing depth assessing untreated chronic periodontitis
yTShTXC9.abstract: Objective: To study the agreement and reproducibility of probing depth(PD) measurements between the electronic computerized periodontal probe for constant pressure and the conventional manual periodontal probe before mechanical treatment in patients with chronic peridodontitis.Methods:PD values of total 144 periodontal sites from 12 patients with chronic periodontitis were duplicately measured using electronic periodontal probe and conventional manual probe before instrumental therapy by two examiners at two visits for the 1st day and the 7th day,respectively,Analysis of the agreement by intraclass correlation coefficient(ICC) and reproducibility between the two different periodontal probes on PD measurement was performed by paired t-test.Different examiners,different visits time,different periodontal pocket depth,different probes(methods) were taken into consideration as possible factors leading to the difference.Results:The agreement and reproduciblity of PD values from two different probes were good(P > 0.05)both between two examiners and two visits.In addition,by linear regression model the difference of PD values between two tools is contributed to the periodontal pocket depth(t=72.42,P<0.001) other than examiners(t=0.26,P=0.793),visits(t=-0.17,P=0.866)or periodontal probes(t=-0.44,P=0.662).Conclusion: Electronic periodontal probe and manual periodontal probe,which are used by examiners trained normally and strictly,are both reliable tools for pretreatment measuring PD values in chronic peridodontitis.

FRoYf4JG.title: The effects of compressive stress on TGF-β1 expression in condylar cartilage in vitro
FRoYf4JG.abstract: Objective:To investigate the expression of transforming growth factor-β1 (TGF-β1) in mandibular condylar chondrocytes after the condylar cartilage was stimulated by compressive stress.Methods:20 condylar cartilage samples were obtained from 10 new borne SD rats and cultured for 24 h.Then,10 samples were treated by a static compressive stress with a magnitude of 10 kPa for 1 h.Another 10 samples without stress treatment were used as the controls. At end of stress stimulation, the expression of TGF-β1 in the samples of both groups was examined by immunohistochemistry and image pattern analysis.Results:The grayscale values of TGF-β1 in perichondrium lay of stress treated and control samples were 159.21±19.84 and 174.20±14.47(P<0.05), in chondroblast layer 125.63 ±13.46 and 141.74±11.76(P<0.01), in hypertrophy layer 165.84±17.38 and 175.96±14.37(P< 0.05 ), respectively.Conclusion:The compressive stress with a magnitude of 10 kPa for 1 hour can increase the expression of TGF-β1 in all layers of condylar cartilage.

55Whzwwk.title: Curative Effect Comparision of Complicated Renal Stone Treatment between Tradional Operation and mPCNL with ESW
55Whzwwk.abstract: Objective To summarize the clinical result of complicated kidney stone treatment.Method we analyzed and compared the therapeutic effect between the tradional operation and mini percutaneous nephrolithotripsy(mPCNL)with Extracorporal shock wave lithotripsy(ESWL)on 88 patients with complicated kidney stone.Two ways of kidney stone eliminating rate were analyzed in statistics.Result Among 88 patients,42 cases were treated by traditional operation,their kidney stone eliminating rate was 69% after one month of the operation;46 cases were by 1-4 times mPCNL with ESWL,the eliminating rate was 93% after one month of the operation.Conclusion 1-4 tines mPCNL with ESWL is effective and safe for treating patients with complicated kidney stone,and its stone eliminating rate is higher than the tradional operation.

R8PoRFh5.title: Effect of three mouthrinses on early in situ biofilm formation
R8PoRFh5.abstract: Objective:To evaluate the influence of tinidazole,cetylpyridinium chloride and chlorhexidine mouthrinses compared with water on in situ biofilm growth.Methods:After a professional scaling,each volunteer wore a special acrylic appliance,in which six glass sheets were inserted to allow the build-up of intra-oral biofilms.The volunteers rinsed for 1 min,with 10 ml of the allocated mouthrinse twice daily.After 48 h of wearing,the specimens with the adhering biofilms were removed from the splints and stained with two fluorescent dyes,which selectively stain vital bacteria green and dead bacteria red.Under the confocal laser scanning microscope biofilm thickness(BT)was evaluated.To examine bacterial vitality(BV%)the biofilms were scanned(1 mm sections)and digital images were made.An image analysis program was used to calculate the mean BV as well as the BV of the single section.After a wash-out period of 14 days a new test cycle was started.Results:The three mouthrinses reduced BT and BV significantly compared with water(P<0.001).Differences between the three mouthrinses were significant(P<0.05).Conclusion:The three mouthrinses shows plaque-reducing and antibacterial properties against the in situ biofilm.Differences exist between the three mouthrinses.

086cJrzt.title: Strengthen the Undergraduate Teaching Quality and Teaching Reform Project Management and Deepen the Construction of Teaching Connotation
086cJrzt.abstract: The quality of undergraduate teaching quality and teaching reform project(UTQTFP) management is directly related to the building results of UTQTFP.The results of practices indicate that it is necessary and feasible to introduce the concept of ISO9000 quality management system into the UTQTFP management process.This promotes strengthen the UTQTFP management and deepen the connotation of the construction of teaching.It helps explore the formation of UTQTFP management that has the distinctive,systemic,scientific,standardized and efficient advantages.

kBI3NrZk.title: The isolation and identification of bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells derived from rabbit mandible]
kBI3NrZk.abstract: To investigate the methods of isolation, culture and identification of BMMSCs derived from rabbit mandible.BMMSCs were collected from rabbit mandible and isolated by density gradient centrifugation. Cells were adherently cultured in vitro, and P2 or P3 BMMSCs populations were collected and examined. Cell growth was observed by inverted microscopy; the propagation of BMMSCs were tested by MTT and a growth curve was drawn after statistical analysis; colony-forming unit-fibroblast(CFU-F) was detected by examination of colony formation; the potential of multi-directional differentiation into osteoblasts, adipocytes and skeletal muscle cells was estimated by pertinent methods; the surface marks of BMMSCs were detected by flow cytometry, the data was analysed using SPSS16.0 software package.The majority of adherent cells were long fusiform, and few were small triangle; the growth curve of BMMSCs showed that every passage experienced incubation period, log phase and platform period; the rate of colony formation was 37%. Growth of BMMSCs represented the appearance of CFU-F; BMMSCs after inducted differentiation showed osteogenic and adipogenic potential. The staining of mineralized nodules was positive by alizarin red S and the positive staining of oil red O appeared in lipid drops around cell nucleus. The staining of skeletal muscle cells was positive by desmin immunofluorescence; the cell surface marks assessed with flow cytometry indicated that these BMMSCs expressed CD90 and CD146 in high percentage (about 98.7% and 98.1%, respectively).The highly uniformed BMMSCs derived from rabbit mandible can be collected. These BMMSCs have the ability of self-replication and propagation, as well as potential of multi-directional differentiation in vitro.

zjyrnGoJ.title: The effect of epristeride on reducing hemorrhage during transurethral resection of prostate
zjyrnGoJ.abstract: Objective To study the effect of epristeride preoperatively taken on reducing bleeding in transurethral resection of prostate.Methods 84 patients were divided into 2 groups,42 of them taken epristeride and the other 42 did not.The amount of bleeding during TURP in both groups was compared.MVD,VEGF and eNOS epressions were measured by ISHSP-method in the resected tissues in both groups.Results The total amount of bleeding per minute and bleeding per gram of the tissues were lower them than those in the control group,(P<0.05).The microvascular density was much less in the epristeride group(P<0.05),The expressions of VEGF,eNOS were also different between the two groups(P<0.01).Conclusion Epristeride might reduce prostate bleeding in TURP.It's mechanism is that epristeride can inhibit the angiogenesis of tissues.

NWQeJEIS.title: Application of Florida periodontal probe for probing the depth during maintenance phase of periodontitis
NWQeJEIS.abstract: Objective To evaluate the reproducibility of probing the depth measurements using Florida pressure-controlled periodontal probe(group FP).Methods The depth of 240 periodontal sites from 10 patients with chronic peridontitis was measured with Florida probe and conventional manual probe(group CP) twice for each site,respectively,during maintenance phase.The reproducibility of measurements was compared between two groups.Results The reproducibility of two groups was very well and similar,which of group FP was slightly better than that of group CP(P>0.05).Conclusion Florida pressure-controlled periodontal probe is an ideal tool for periodontal examination.

XcueWpAt.title: Expression of Bone Morphogenetic Protein (BMP)-4 mRNA in Mouse Embryonic Tooth Development
XcueWpAt.abstract: Objective The purpose of this paper was to investigate the expression of bone morphogenetic protein(BMP)-4 mRNA in the developing molars of mice,and discuss its effect and significance in different stages of tooth development.Methods The expression of BMP-4 mRNA were examined in developing mouse molars between the 13th and the 19th(the 13th embryonic day and the 19th embryonic day),by using in situ hybridization methods.Results BMP4 mRNA positive cells were detected at different stages of tooth development.And they were regularly concentrated in the dental epithelium cells and the mesenchymal cells.Conclusion BMP4 distributions indicate that it maybe participates in during the development of mouse embryonic teeth.

XqA6uKjV.title: Effects of CTGF on VEGF Expression in Periodontal Ligament Fibroblasts
XqA6uKjV.abstract: Objective To study the effects of CTGF on VEGF expression in human periodontal ligament fibroblasts.Methods The HPLFs were obtained by tissue culture,and detected by immunohistochemical stain.CTGF (5,10,50,100 ng/mL) were added into the HPLFs which were passed fifth generation,and cultured. 48 hours later,the cells were collected and analyzed by immunohistochemical stain and automatic image analysis system to detect the VEGF expression in treated HPLFs.Results HPLFs got from tissue culture were confirmed by morphology and immunohistochemical detection.The CTGF (5～100 ng/mL) up-regulated VEGF expression in HPLFs.The expression of VEGF reached the peak when the concentration of CTGF was 10 ng/mL. Conclusion CTGF can effectively increse the expresion of VEGF in HPLFs.

JDbAFMxW.title: The Expression of CTGF in Condyle Cartilage under Asymmetric Masticatory Force
JDbAFMxW.abstract: Objective To investigate the effect of the asymmetric of masticatory force on the remodeling of bilateral mandibular condylar cartilage of SD rats. Methods The animal models were established respectively by excising the unilateral temporalis, and injecting botulinum toxin A into the unilateral masseter. Dividing three batch processing 3 weeks,6 weeks,and 9 weeks after the animal modeling, six rats were killed in each group. The expression of CTGF in condylar cartilage was observed by immunohistochemical staining. Results CTGF expressed in proliferative layer,chondroblast layer and hypertrophic layer of the condylar cartilage. The expression of CTGF in the experimental groups was increased than control groups(P<0.05). There was no significant difference between the left and right side in the experimental groups(P>0.05),the expression of CTGF after 6 weeks of operation was stronger than the group after 3 weeks of operation,the expression of CTGF after 9 weeks of operation was the strongest than all of other groups(P<0.05). Conclusions The asymmetric of masticatory force can up-regulate the expression of CTGF mRNA in rat mandibular condylar chondrocytes. CTGF induces the effect of stress-mediated on the mandibular condylar cartilage remodeling.

i4hZ3imo.title: Role of PTHrP in the Development of Meckel's Cartilage
i4hZ3imo.abstract: Objective To observe the temporal and spatial changes of parathyroid hormone-related protein(PTHrP)in Meckel's cartilage during the development mandible of SD rats,and to explore the role of PTHrP in the development of Meckel's cartilage.Method The expressions of PTHrP and PTHrP mRNA in Meckel's cartilage during the development mandible of E13-19d SD fetal rats were detected by immunohistochemical staining and in situ hybridization staining.Results During the 13rd and 15th day of the embryo,the strong positive expression of PTHrP was detected in the nucleus and cytoplasm of the preceding Meckel's cartilage,and was detected more obvious in the nucleus of hypertrophic cartilage cells.PTHrPmRNA and PTHrP protein were expressed in the same position.During the 17 th and 19th day of the embryo,there were the ossifications of Meckel's front-end cartilage.On the 17th day,the weakly positive expression of PTHrP protein was detected in the hypertrophic cartilage nucleus near the Meckel's cartilage osteogenesis,and the negative expression of PTHrP mRNA was detected.On the 19th day,the negative expression of PTHrP protein and mRNA were detected.but the strong positive expression of PTHrP protein and mRNA were detected away from the Meckel's front-end cartilage osteogenesis,and were significant in the nucleus.Conclusions There are specific temporal and spatial changes on the expressionof PTHrP in the Meckel's front-end cartilage chondrocytes.PTHrP is possibly produced by Meckel's cartilage chondrocytes,as an autocrine factor regulating Meckel's cartilage cell proliferation and differentiation.

pR8oc2XW.title: The Treatment of 28 Patients with Upper Ureteral Calculi
pR8oc2XW.abstract: Objective To evaluate the treatment of upper ureteral calculi.Method Clinical data of 208 cases of upper ureteral calculi were retrospectively analysed.Results Among the 208 patients with upper ureteral calculi,135 patients were treated with extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy(ESWL),65 patients were treated with ureteroscopic lithotripsy(URSL),6 patients were treated with minimally invasive percutaneous nephrolithotomy(MPCNL),2 patients were treated with ureterolithotomy.Conclusion We should choose a reasonable and effective treatment for patients with upper ureteral calculi according to their situation.

u7JrUHL0.title: Expression and clinical significance of XIAP in mucoepidermoid carcinoma of salivary glands
u7JrUHL0.abstract: Objective To evaluate the expression of x-linked inhibitor of apoptosis protein(XIAP)in MEC. Methods Immunohistochemical staining method was used to quantify the protein expression levels of XIAP in 25 cases of MEC.Results XIAP was highly expreessed in MEC,but not expressed or lowly expressed in normal salivary gland tissues.The XIAP rales of MEC and normal salivary gland tissues were 84%(21/25)and 0.00%(0/10)respectively(P< 0.01).The expression of XIAP in the tissue of MEC was correlated with pathologic differentiation,but was not correlated with tumor position,clinicopathologic stage,lymphatic metastasis(P>0.05).Conclusion The high expression of XIAP in MEC may play an important role in the develop-ment of MEC.

RQPG15Xe.title: Effects of Condylar Process Fracture on Condyle and Mandible in Rats
RQPG15Xe.abstract: Objective To establish rat model of condylar process fracture and to examine the effects of this fracture on condyle and mandibular bone in rats.Methods Unilateral condylar process fracture was performed on SD rats using an eye scissors.Contralateral side,sham- operated group and un- operated group were set up as control groups.All of the rats were killed after 1,3,5,or 9 weeks.The measurement and the imageology observation of mandibular and candylar process were conducted.Results The height of the mandibular ramus, the length and width of the mandibular body,and the condyle were smaller on the ipsilateral side than those on the contralateral side and unoperated group.The condyle on the ipsilateral side exhibited morphological changes. Conclusions This rat model of the condylar process fracture shows great practicability and reproducibility.After the fracture,the change of stress produces a series of physical responses in the condyle and mandible and lead to the asymmetry of them in rats.

4e5GBQOl.title: Bipolar Transurethral Plasmakinefic Prostatectomy for 87 Cases of Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia
4e5GBQOl.abstract: Objective To evaluate the curative effect of bipolar transurethral plasmakinetic prostateetomy(TUPKP)in the treatment of benign prostate hyperplasia(BPH).Method We summarized the clinical data of 89 patients with BPH treated with TUPKP.Results The resected tissues weighed 21～103 g,52 g on average.The operation lasted 25～100 min,55 min on average.No transurethral resection syndrome(TURS) occurred.The patients were followed up for 3～9 months,the maximum flow rate(MFR)increased from(7.5±3.8)mL/s to(23.2±5.1)mL/s;the average flow rate(AFR)increased from(5.3±0.4)mL/s to(11.8±1.9)mL/s;the international prostate symptom score(IPSS)decreased from(27.3±3.4)to(6.2±1.9);the residual urine(RU)decreased from(127.6± 34.3)mL to(16.9±6.5)mL;the quality of life(QOL)scores decreased from(5.3±0.8)to(1.9±0.3),the difference was statistically significant between before and after surgery(P<0.05).Conclusion TUPKP is a minimally invasive,safe,reliable,and effective treatment with few complications for BPH.

NLEwh2AF.title: Clinical symptoms and diagnosis of vesical mucous membrane leukoplaskia
NLEwh2AF.abstract: 【Objective】 To explore the clinical symptoms and diagnostic criteria of vesical mucous membrane leukoplaskia to prevent it's local pathological malignant change.【Methods】The patients' history were investigated,cystoscopy and pathology examination were performed.【Results】The symptoms of 137 patients with urinary urgency,urinary frequency,urinary pain,and uncomfortable lower abdoment have been repeatedly appeared over a long period of time.The vesical leukoplaskia pathological change as "Snow pile"in the trigone of bladder can be observed with cystoscopy.The pathological report concluded squamous intraepithelial metaplasia,partial cells abnormal model change.【Conclusion】A Routine Urine Test,Ultrasound B,KUB,IVP,CT,MRI,etc.are only the basis of distinguishing diagnosis.Vesical mucous membrane leukoplaskia is dependent on cystoscopy and pathology examination.A typical pathological change can be observed with cystoscopy.TUR may trate the Vesical mucous membrane leukplaskia.

AN14cVOZ.title: Effect of Unilateral Condylectomy on the Proliferation and Apoptosis of the Opposite Condylar Chondrocytes
AN14cVOZ.abstract: Objective To investigate the effect of unilateral condylectomy on the proliferation and apoptosis of the opposite condylar chondrocytes.Methods Twenty-four 5～6 months old Japanese big-ear rabbits were randomly divided into 2 groups:the blank control group and the operation group.Rabbits in the opetation group were performed removing the right condylar.The left condylar(the nonoperative side)cartilages of each group were dissected in 2 months and 4 months after the operation accordingly.Immunohistochemical staining was used to qualitively examine the PCNA positive cell.TUNEL was chosen to detect the apoptotic cell.Results Immunohistochemical staining and TUNEL showed that: compared with the blank control group at the same time-points,the number of the PCNA positive cells decreased significantly in both 2 months and 4 months operation group;while the number of TUNEL positive cells increased significantly in both 2 months and 4 months operate group(P<0.05).Compared with the operation group in 2 months after the operation,the number of the PCNA positive cells decreased significantly in the operation group in 4 months after the operation;while the number of TUNEL positive cells increased significantly(P<0.05).Conclusion Unilateral condylectomy can decrese the proliferation capacity and increase apoptosis of the opposite condylar chondrocytes.

5LticuDA.title: Establishment of Rat Model of Orthodontic Tooth Movement
5LticuDA.abstract: Objective To construct a rat model of orthodontic tooth movement.Methods The experiment was carried on 45 male SD rats.The left side of jaws were attached orthodontic appliances and selected as experiment group,the right side attached nothing and selected as control group.The orthodontic procedure included moving the maxillary first molar with the central incisor as anchor.The break rates of the appliances were calculated,the tooth movement and the periodontal histology changes were oberserved.Results The break rate was 2.2%.The maxillary first molar moves closer to the middle,and there was an obvious gaps between the first molar and the second molar.Conclusion The rat model of orthodontic tooth movement was established successfully.

lx9HP3hI.title: Efficacy Observation of Yindanxinnaotong Soft Capsules Combined with isosorbide 5-mononitrate and Metoprolol Tartrate Tablet for Coronary Disease and Angina Pectoris
lx9HP3hI.abstract: Objective To observe the therapeutic effect of Yindanxinnaotong Soft Capsules combined with two chemicals for coronary disease angina pectoris.Methods 80 cases which were up to the diagnosis standard were randomly divided into control group(n=40) and treatment group(n= 40).Control groups were treated with the routine isosorbide 5-mononitrate sustained release tablets(10～20 mg,bid),MetoprololTartrateTablets(12.5～ 25mg,qd).Treatment group were additionally treated with 2 to 4 Yindanxinnaotong Soft Capsules,tid,p.o,with treating course of 30 days.Results The total efficacy rate of angina pectoris and the electrocardiogram were 80.85% and 74.47% for treatment group while 61.36% and 56.82% for control group.There was significant difference between two groups(P<0.05).Conclusion The therapeutic effect is improved by using Yindanxinnaotong Soft Capsules combined with isesorbide 5-mononitrate sustained release tablets,MetoprololTartrateTablets for coronary disease angina pectoris.

eGy0Ld0Q.title: Effects of cyclosporin A on apoptosis of gingival keratinocytes in mice
eGy0Ld0Q.abstract: Objective To investigate the mechanism of cyclosporin A(CsA)-induced murine gingival epithelial hyperplasia.Methods 6-week-old male,ICR mice received CsA dissolved in olive oil(30 mgCsA/kg body weight) daily through gastric feeding.Mice were chosen randomly to sacrifice after 1,2,4,6 wk,respectively.4 μm serial longitudinal-sections were processed in the gingivae of central incisors and the palatal mucosa,then determined the apoptotic rates of the keratinocytes in such parts as oral epithelium(OE),oral sulcular epithelium(OSE) of gingivae and palatal mucosa by in situ TUNEL assay.Results After 1 and 2 wk,the apoptotic rates of keratinocytes in OSE were significantly decreased in the test group while there were no statistical differences between the two groups after 4 wk and 6 wk.Moreover,TUNEL-positive cells were mainly seen in the superficial layers in the test group,whereas in the inner being they were also seen in the control.And there were no significant changes in the percentages of apoptotic epithelia in OE and palatal mucosa at any observation time.Conclusion CsA can inhibit the apoptosis of keratinocytes in OSE at early time.This indicates that the mechanism of CsA-induced gingival epithelial overgrowth may be associated with its inhibiting apoptosis of keratinocytes in OSE.

x231DmqR.title: Ureteroscope Pneumatic Lithotripsy in the Treatment of Middle and Lower Ureterolith
x231DmqR.abstract: Objective To evaluate the curative effect and the treatment and prevention of complication of ureteroscope pneumatic lithotripsy in the treatment of middle and lower ureterolith.Method Clinical data of 396 cases of middle and lower ureterolith treated with ureteroscope pneumatic lithotripsy were reviewed.Results The success rate of ureteroscope pneumatic lithotripsy was 92.68%(367/396 cases),the incidence of complications was 5.3%(21/396 cases).Conclusion The treatment of ureterolith with ureteroscope pneumatic lithotripsy is a safe,reliable,and effective treatment with less trauma,high success rate,and few complications.

K0oct6U0.title: Role of Programmed Cell Death (Apoptosis)in the Disappearance of Meckel's Cartilage
K0oct6U0.abstract: Objective To observe the changes of programmed cell death(apoptosis)in Meckel's cartilage during the development mandible of SD rats.Method The expression of apoptotic cells in Meckel's cartilage during the mandible development of E13-19 d SD fetal rat was detected by TUNEL.Results In 13 days to 19 days embryo,the sporadic apoptotic cells were detected in Meckel's mouth cartilage cells,and a small number of apoptotic cells were observed in Meckel's cartilage perichondrium.In the 17 days to 19 days embryo,the ossification of Meckel's front-end cartilage was found,and the TUNEL staining positive cells were near to the ossification site at the Meckel's cartilage chondrocytes.The weakly positive expressions of Meckel's cartilage chondrocytes for TUNEL staining were detected at the preceding away from the ossification and the middle of Meckel's cartilage.In 17 days to 19 days embryo,Meckel's cartilage perichondrium appeared disintegration at the front-end and the middle of Meckel's cartilage,and these cells were positive by TUNEL staining,some apoptotic cells gathered into a group.Apoptotic cells were also observed in the ossification of Meckel's cartilage,were weakly positive by TUNEL staining.Conclusions The demise of the Meckel's cartilage perichondrium cells is mainly in the form of apoptosis.Only part of Meckel's cartilage chondrocytes disappear through apoptosis.

2qeEA1RX.title: Effect of Unilateral Condylectomy on the Cell Apoptosis of Condylar Cartilage on the Opposite Side
2qeEA1RX.abstract: Objective To investigate the effect of unilateral condylectomy on the cell apoptosis of condylar cartilage on the opposite side.Methods Twenty-four 5～6 months old Japanese big-ear rabbits were randomly divided into 2 groups:the control group and the operation group.The opetation group was created by removing the right condylar process.The left condylar cartilage was dissected 2 months and 4 months after the operation,and TUNEL was used to detect the apoptotic cell.Result Compared with the control group,the number of apoptotic cells increased significantly in operation group 2 months and 4 months after operation(P<0.05),and the increase 4 months after operation was more significant than the 2 months after operation(P<0.05).Conclusion Unilateral condylectomy will increase the number of apoptotic cells of the condylar cartilage on the opposite side.

RY7x3kfn.title: The Effect of Growth Differentiation Factor-5 on the Mandibular Condylar Cartilage of Developing Temporomandibular Joint
RY7x3kfn.abstract: Objective To study the expression of growth differentiation factor-5(GDF-5)in the mandibular condylar cartilage of developing temporomandibular joint of rat fetuses,and to explore the role of(GDF-5)in the development of mandibular condylar cartilage.Method A series of fetal rat TMJ developing model(E13,15,17,19,and 21 d)was built histologically.Expression of growth differentiation factor-5(GDF-5)protein in the mandibular condylar cartilage of developing temporomandibular joint of SD rats in different development stage was observed by S-P immunohistochemical staining.Results The expression of GDF-5 has time and space specificity in the development of mandibular condylar cartilage.GDF-5 began expressd in the chondroblastic cell layer on E13 d,and the expression level was highest in the cartilage cell layer and prolifetation cell layer on E15 d,then decreased.The expression of GDF-5 was low in mastocyte layer on E15 d,increase with age,then decreased on E21 d.There were different levels in expression of GDF-5 in the condylar cartilage of developing temporomandibular joint.Conclusions GDF-5 may be involved in the modulation of the development,regeneration and structure maintenance of chondrocyte.

GsBoLujk.title: Effects of Cyclosporin A on apoptosis and proliferation of gingival epithelial cells of mice
GsBoLujk.abstract: Objective To investigate the effects of Cyclosporin A on the apoptosis and proliferation of gingival epithelium cells of mice. Methods Mice were fed with CsA and injected with BrdU eight days later. Mice's gingival and palatal tissues were taken out for BrdU staining in different times and observed with light microscopy. Results The number of BrdU staining cells in gingiva has no difference between the CsA-treated group and controls. Meanwhile,the cell life was prolongated but not that of the palatal epithelium. Conlusions CsA can depress the apoptosis of mice's gingival epithelium by prolongating cell life instead of inducing the proliferation of cells.

DjZczTTn.abstract: As one of the important target cells,human periodontal ligament fibroblasts(HPLFs)have been widely used in orthodontics,periodontal and implant.This review describes the methods and cautions of culture of human periodontal ligament fibroblasts in vitro.

gii2Ke7g.title: Pneumatic lithotripsy through ureteroscope for treating ureteral calculi (A report of 226 cases)
gii2Ke7g.abstract: [Objective] To investigate the effects of pneumatic lithotripsy through rigid ureteroscope for the treatment of ureteral calculi. [Method] 226 patients with the disease of ureteral calculi were treated with pneumatic lithotripsy through ureteroscope. [Results] 95.6% (216/226) of stones were fragmented. 72.6% (164/226) of stones were taken out completely on one occasion only. Seven stones moved up into the pelvises. A tube was put in and then ESWL was used. Three of them were operated on because of their serious narrow ureters and the ureteroscope could not get into them. Serious infection and the ureter tearing did not occur in them. [Conclusion] Pneumatic lithotripsy through rigid transurethral ureteroscope is not only safe, dependable, but also less invasive with complete clearance of the calculi. It is the best way to cure the disease of calculi in the middle and distal ureter.

sx6Mdmk2.title: Clinical Observation on Yindan Xinnaotong Capsule in Treating Senile Unstable Angina Pectoris
sx6Mdmk2.abstract: Objective Discussion of Yindan Xinnaotong through the old non-clinical treatment of unstable angina. Methods Unstable angina patients in routine treatment on the basis of angina pectoris with Yindan Xinnaotong every three goals,three times a day,unstable angina patients treated as ordinary routine angina,two groups of treatment for 8 weeks. Results Yindan Xinnaotong symptoms of unstable angina pectoris treated total effective rate was 87.5%,adding Yindan Xinnaotong through the treatment group,low shear whole blood viscosity,high shear and reduced red blood cell aggregation index was significantly higher than normal group difference. Add Yindan Xinnaotong countless treated group of brain and nitric oxide endothelial function decline in treatment group,and NO symptoms,blood viscosity,ET than in control group(P<0.05,P<0.01) . Conclusion Yindan Xinnaotong through the clinical treatment of unstable angina effect is significant,is the effective drug.

4BfAcZw6.title: Effects of CTGF on the periodontal tissue remolding during orthodontic tooth movement
4BfAcZw6.abstract: Objective:To study the effects of CTGF on the periodontal tissue remolding during orthodontic tooth movement.Methods:A mouse model of orthodontic tooth movement was established.The CTGF and NS were injected into the periodontal tissue of the first molar.HE staining,immunohistochemical staining and automatic image analysis system were used to detect the changes of periodontal tissue and the expression of VEGF.Results:The periodontal tissue remolding accompanied the over expression of VEGF during the orthodontic tooth movement.At day 7,the remolding was most active and the expression of VEGF was the highest.CTGF injection induced acceleration of periodontal remolding and up-regulating the expression of VEGF during orthodontic tooth movement,especially at day 7 and day 15 after the orthodontic force were applied.Conclusion:In the mouse model of orthodontic tooth movement,periodontal CTGF injection induces over expression of VEGF and accelerates the periodontal remodeling during orthodontic tooth movement.

Ur5ZqLe5.title: Dynamic analysis and accumulation process recovery of typical reservoirs in Zhenjing region,south of Ordos Basin
Ur5ZqLe5.abstract: The dynamic analyses of typical reservoirs in Zhenjing region of the southern Ordos Basin have been carried out based on pore evolution history recovery,petroleum generation history thermal simulation and fluid inclusion analyses.The Chang8 lithologic traps were formed since the late Jurassic(160 Ma).The Chang7 source rocks began to generate petroleum at the end of Jurassic(140 Ma) and achieved the peak at the end of early Cretaceous(100 Ma).The Chang8 reservoirs were formed during 2 stages,including the medium of early Cretaceous(130 Ma) and the beginning of late Cretaceous(90 Ma).The times for trap formation,petroleum generation and reservoir formation matched well,which was favorable for the formation of Chang8 reservoirs.The charging and accumulation processes of petroleum were recovered according to the studies of tectonic evolution.A dynamic evolution model illustrating the process of reservoir formation was made,characterized by "multiple stages of accumulation,mainly formed during the middle stage and late stage adjustment".

VXcxFCMo.title: An analysis of the main controlling factors of the reservoir formation of Upper Triassic Yanchang Formation in Ordos Basin
VXcxFCMo.abstract: It is concluded that there are favorable conditions for oil accumulation in Zhenjing Area through the detailed analysis of many aspects of the Upper Triassic Yanchang Formation in Ordos Basin, such as hydrocarbon source conditions, reservoir conditions, reservoir-cap rock combination and the type trap. The research results of the controlling factors of oil reservoirs and the enrichment regularity indicate that the tectonic evolution controls oil reservoir adjusting direction, old oil reservoir migrates to the north-east direction. Organic matter abundance distribution of hydrocarbon source rocks controls the oil accumulation. The area where the organic matter abundance is more than 1 percent has favorable conditions for oil accumulation. The favorable deposit belts control the enrichment of oil and the underwater distributary channel of deltaicfront subfacies are close to hydrocarbon sources, and have better sand body physical properties and a large thickness, making it a favorable site for the accumulation of petroleum. The dynamic reduction of fluid controls the migration direction of petroleum in reservoring time. The bigger the dynamic reduction of fluid is, the more petroleum will be accumulated. The fracture serves as the migration channels for the hydrocarbon enrichment, and the porosity increasing caused by the fracture will further affect the hydrocarbon enrichment.

m4Yd4Cvj.title: Analysis on accumulation condition of natural gas in southern Ordos Basin in Ordovician
m4Yd4Cvj.abstract: The study of hydrocarbon source condition,formation mechanism of reservoirs and trap characteristics of the Ordovician weathering crust gas accumulation in southern Ordos Basin showed that the Huangling paleouplift separated the Qinling aulacogen and Huabei sea during Early Ordovician,and formed evaporate platform slope gypsum dolomite sediments in northern paleuplift.The gypsum dolomites and gypsum-bearing dolomites formed various porous reservoirs by differences dissolution in the period of Caledonian orogeny in northern Huangling paleouplift,which uplifted accompanying with the Ordos Basin.The widespread dolomites were characterized by fine-grained dolomite honeycomb-like,dolomite pinhole-like and dolomite breccia shown in drilling.During the Hercynian-Indosinian,the paleouplift at the superior site by accepting the migration fluid came from Qinling aulacogen,and more old reservoirs have been found on the north and south wings of the Huangling paleouplift.The oil that stored in old reservoirs was transformed into gas by high palaeotemperature during the Late Jurassic-Early Cretaceous,which provided adequate gas source to Fuxian slope.Fuxian-Ganquan area became favorable for gas exploration as the dense rock band in Mizhi depression which provided regional trap condition for weathering crust natural gas gathering.

TMtrJa7e.title: Major factors controlling reservoir quality of the Upper Triassic Chang 8 sandstones in Fuxian, Ordos Basin
TMtrJa7e.abstract: The reservoir quality is strongly influenced by the depositional microfacies, composition and grain size of sandstones, and diagenesis of the Chang 8 subaqueous distribution channel sandbodies of Upper Triassic delta-front facies in Fuxian. Depositional microfacies belts controlled reservoir by sand body types and characteristics of properties. Reservoir performances of sandbodies show significant difference in different depositional microfacies. Porosity and permeability of subaqueous distribution channel sandbodies in delta-front is the highest in related sandbodies, and interdistributary bayisthe worst by small granularity, more matrix, strong mechanical compaction prevented flowing of late dissolution fluid. The strong mechanical compaction, pressure-solution and cementation of authogenetic minerals reduced reservoir performances of sandstones. Dissolutions caused by freshwater leaching and organic acids have significance for improving reservoir.

KqgwyrDO.title: Features of Mesozoic source rocks and oil-source correlation in southern Ordos Basin
KqgwyrDO.abstract: Based on the studies of carbon isotopes and biomarkers,only one set of effective source rock was identified in Mesozoic in the southern Ordos Basin,that is,dark shale with big thickness deposited in lacustrine environment in the Upper Triassic Yanchang Formation.The source rocks mainly distributed in Qingyang,Zhengning,Zhiluo,Wuqi,Yanchi and Huanxian County.The dark shale in the seventh member of Yanchang Formation was the most favorable source rock in the study area,providing oil and gas for not only itself but also the Fuxian,Yan'an and Zhiluo Formations of Jurassic.With weak structural fluctuation and gentle stratigraphic dip angle(usually below 1°),hydrocarbon had migrated for short distance before accumulating in low-porosity and low-permeability reservoirs.Sand bodies were poorly connected and few fractures worked as vertical migration pathways.Hydrocarbon mainly accumulated in lacustrine depressions or neighboring areas.The results showed that the favorable places for prospecting in the southern Ordos Basin should be the lithologic traps close to the source rocks in Yanchang Formation.
